image.altText: A young white woman carefully lifting a toddler up at a playground

items.synopsis: New research suggests the number of Australian women who sustain life-altering injuries to their pelvic floor after birth is far higher than acknowledged.

title.children: Pelvic floor physio before and after childbirth could reduce Australia's 'hidden epidemic'

image.altText: a man with his arms folded looks at the camera while standing in his kitchen

items.synopsis: Tristan Hockings claims his hearing problems "significantly deteriorated" after the alleged assault in July 2019, forcing him to leave his job as a nurse.

title.children: Tristan went on a date that ended in a police raid. Now he's suing police for alleged assault

image.altText: A headshot of Belinda

items.synopsis: Professional garbologist Bel has so little landfill waste she's ditched her red bin. Here's how she did it.

title.children: Could you do without your red garbage bin? This 'garbologist' has managed to ditch hers

image.altText: A cow stands in a her wearing a small device on a collar

items.synopsis: Each morning when Tasmanian farmer Duncan Macdonald wakes up and heads to the milking shed, his herd of dairy cows is already there and waiting — thanks to "virtual fencing" technology.

title.children: 'We turn up and the cows are there, ready to be milked': The new tech giving farmers a sleep-in

items.synopsis: In 1994, a looter codenamed The Falcon dug up an ancient treasure that decades later would end up in an Australian gallery. Now, it's being given back.

title.children: He dug up an ancient treasure. He had no idea the eye-watering price it would later fetch

image.altText: Anthony Albanese pointing in question time.

items.synopsis: From voice to truth to treaty and Makarrata, there are a lot of words being thrown around in the Voice to Parliament debate coming from Canberra. So, what have they got to do with the upcoming referendum?

title.children: Is there treaty in the Voice? What is treaty and truth-telling? Voice to Parliament questions answered

image.altText: A barista makes a coffee on a machine at a cafe

items.synopsis: A record number of Australians are working multiple jobs, as employees try to keep up with a near 10 per cent surge in the cost of living.

title.children: A record number of Australians are working multiple jobs to 'keep their heads above water'

image.altText: A large piece of machinery being pulled from the water.

items.synopsis: The flying operations for the Taipan helicopter fleet are becoming increasingly uncertain, as the devastating recovery operation from last week continues.

title.children: Growing doubts over whether troubled Taipan helicopters will return to duty

image.altText: Three women sit on a reformer pilates bed holding their babies

items.synopsis: The pelvic floor is something most people don't talk about and many don't even know about. Here's why it's important and how to look after yours.

title.children: We rarely talk about pelvic floors. Here's why it's important and how to look after yours

image.altText: Angela Fitzwater sits in a chair in a home, dressed warmly as she looks forward with a serious expression.

items.synopsis: After falling victim to scams, the 83-year-old spent three months chasing an answer from her bank's fraud department.

title.children: Angela realised the 'hi mum' scam too late — but feels her bank let her down with what came next

image.altText: Paul McCartney raises his arms on stage

items.synopsis: Whenever Paul McCartney picks up the guitar to compose new music he still wonders what John Lennon would make of it.

title.children: 'I'm singing with my old buddy again': Paul McCartney on how AI is bringing John Lennon back on stage

image.altText: Girl standing with her back to the camera, wearing a backpack.

items.synopsis: Universities are failing to meet a key recommendation set out by the Australian Human Rights Commission to support students who are victims of sexual violence, as pressure grows on the federal government to hold the sector accountable.

title.children: 'They leave our cries unheard': Universities accused of failing sexual assault victims

image.altText: AI companies have been accused of unlawfully using copyrighted content

items.synopsis: The media and arts union tell the government AI owners should pay compensation for the content used to train their tools, while big tech asks for exemptions from copyright laws.

title.children: Fight brews on AI copyright law, as unions say big tech must pay to train AI, while Google, Microsoft ask for exemptions

image.altText: A drawing of a marine mammal built somewhat like a manatee under the ocean

items.synopsis: Italian researchers estimate Perucetus, or "colossal Peruvian whale", was about 20 metres long and weighed up to 340 tonnes, a mass greater than the blue whale and the largest dinosaurs.

title.children: Could this 'colossal Peruvian whale' be the biggest animal ever on Earth?

image.altText: Sydney skyline at night.

items.synopsis: Australia's biggest companies are detailing the impact cost-of-living pressures and high interest rates have had on their bottom line. Analysts say the results will give an early warning sign as to where the economy is heading.

title.children: Rising interest rates have been costing corporate Australia. We're about to find out just how much

image.altText: Brazilian footballer Andressa cries and is is comforted by teammates.

items.synopsis: The Reggae Girlz stun Brazil by holding on for a draw, meaning Marta and her team are eliminated at the group stage.

title.children: Tears flow as Jamaica expel Brazil and legendary striker Marta from World Cup

image.altText: Phillip Di Bella

items.synopsis: The majority of small business owners are earning less than their own employees, according to new data from the Australian Small Business Ombudsman.

title.children: Cafe owner Phillip says costs are too high as a report finds many small businesses make zero profit

image.altText: Blue ocean lapping up against white sand and a grassy hill with tall palm trees.

items.synopsis: A global minimum tax is designed to stop multinationals avoiding taxes. But some experts argue it may have unintended consequences.

title.children: Australia has a plan to stop corporations from evading tax offshore. It might backfire

image.altText: Two people chat outside a shop.

items.synopsis: A lack of affordable and available housing is driving young families from Port Fairy, prompting fears for the future of the town's two primary schools.

title.children: Tourist town losing the people who 'give it life' as median house price nudges $1m

image.altText: A blue grey building with black windows across the front and a sign reading: "Solomon Star".

items.synopsis: Solomon Islands' longest running newspaper promised China favourable coverage in return for money, and a leaked email has revealed concerns around stories that could damage the Solomon Star's ability to access further funds from Beijing.

title.children: 'China is a doer not a talker': Leaked email shows China's influence over Solomon Islands media

image.altText: A person with their hand on a fuel pump puts fuel into their car.

items.synopsis: The Papua New Guinea government is deeply concerned about ongoing fuel supply in the country, after declaring a snap 30-day national emergency on Monday. Here's how we got here.

title.children: PNG's central bank is feuding with a major fuel supplier. Now the government has declared a national emergency

image.altText: Unidentified child drawing.

items.synopsis: Gaye was sexually abused when she was a young child. Warning signs at the time were ignored or brushed under the carpet and when her fragments of memories of the abuse came together years later, she found she was still being "silenced".

title.children: Five-year-old Gaye drew men differently to other kids. Her drawings held a sinister revelation

image.altText: long ladder with two people in hard hats on it, reaching up to a burning and collapsed building

items.synopsis: Grain meant to go to African nations, China and Israel is destroyed in what Ukraine says was a targeted attack by Russia.

title.children: Russia damages almost 40,000 tonnes of grain, some of it meant for Africa

image.altText: Three women and survivors of sexual abuse stand on a flight of stairs leading to the Maroochydore District Court.

items.synopsis: Four survivors of sexual abuse have told their story about a Sunshine Coast man who sexually assaulted them as children and how it severely impacted every aspect of their lives.

title.children: Decades after their abuse ended, four women unite to jail a paedophile

image.altText: Karen Kennedy and her son Aaron Kennedy

items.synopsis: A clinic with ties to a cult that teaches that disability is "karma" has received thousands of dollars under the NDIS scheme.

title.children: Aaron's carer, who was funded by NDIS, was part of a 'cult' that teaches that disabilities are 'karma'

image.altText: A woman and child are using a mobile phone on a park bench.

items.synopsis: Chinese children and teens will be cut off from accessing the internet at night under rules aimed at fighting internet addiction.

title.children: China cracks down on smartphone and internet use for minors

image.altText: Local residents being evacuated on a forklift during China's flooding.

items.synopsis: While 27 people are reported missing, many more are caught in the devastation caused by remnants of Typhoon Doksuri, which has battered northern China for four days.

title.children: 'Not enough time to evacuate': Contact lost with hundreds of residents trapped by floods in China

image.altText: Looma community.

items.synopsis: A coronial inquest hears how a forbidden relationship involving a woman with the "wrong skin" may have sparked a tribal punishment that claimed the life of an Indigenous man 30 years ago.

title.children: 'A hiding with sticks': Court hears forbidden relationship may have cost Indigenous man his life

image.altText: Green racing car on winding road.

items.synopsis: Motorsport Australia's CEO says he is disappointed Targa will "go it alone" with the tarmac rally event without waiting for his organisation to implement new regulations following four competitor deaths in two years.

title.children: Motorsport boss stunned Targa to continue without governing body's blessing

image.altText: A close up of Trump smiling in front of the stars of the American flag.

items.synopsis: The federal investigation of the former US president is just the latest criminal case against Donald Trump as he runs for the White House in 2024.

title.children: Can't keep up with Donald Trump's legal troubles? We're tracking his various investigations

image.altText: A power police with three wires, one of which has been cut.

items.synopsis: The state's biggest electricity distributor says thieves are putting their lives at risk by cutting down power poles to steal and sell copper wiring.

title.children: Copper thieves 'taking chainsaws and hacksaws' to power poles, say NSW police

image.altText: Lizzo stands on stage at Splendour In The Grass in a black leather outfit.

items.synopsis: Three dancers who previously worked with Lizzo have accused the singer of creating a hostile work environment with alleged incidents occurring between 2021 and 2023.

title.children: Lizzo's former dancers file lawsuit against singer

image.altText: Human hands hold a Tasmanian devil joey

items.synopsis: Named Milo the Milestone Devil, the four-month-old joey was discovered during a regular pouch inspection, meaning the wildlife sanctuary has produced 500 joeys since it was launched on the mainland during 2011.

title.children: An 'absolute milestone' for Aussie Ark sanctuary as Milo the Tasmanian devil joey emerges in NSW

image.altText: A portrait shot of a clean-shaven man with black hair, outdoors.

items.synopsis: NSW Premier Chris Minns announced in a snap press conference on Wednesday that Tim Crakanthorp will step down after a significant breach of the ministerial code.

title.children: NSW Premier refers cabinet minister to corruption watchdog, asks him to step down

image.altText: An SA Police logo on the shoulder of a police officer's uniform.

items.synopsis: South Australian police arrest 36 child sex offenders, including five allegedly in possession of child exploitation material, in a statewide operation targeting breaches of sex offender registration laws.

title.children: Dozens of paedophiles arrested across SA for breaching legal obligations
